ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Gained an appreciation of the theory behind x-ray crystallography on a more rigorous level than the introductory macromolecular structure and biophysical analysis in the same department.
I learned about x-tay crystallography in more depth than previously learned form the Macromolecular Interactions course that was offered in the Fall.
I learnt a lot of crystallography knowledge in this class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Prof. Steitz's notes are hard to decipher, as were his lectures. However, by providing the texts he based the course off of, I was able to follow along.
This class is really good, but I really want some slides or printed words, instead of the manuscripts of the lecturer.

The order of topics was natural which was a strength. A weakness is that the class felt rough. A way to improve this is to provide better notes, if at all, as a lot of time was taken trying to read what was given to us.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if they are looking to do research using x-ray crystallography and need a crash course in how it actually works and how to understand what you're actually doing in your experiments.
Yes, because it introduce lots of things about crystallography.
